I lived in the Ashanti region of Ghana for a year while teaching at a Teacher Training College in Akrokerri. Electricity was elusive even on that campus. Especially during showers in the rainy season! When possible, I had to charge my laptop all day to have a few hours in the ptich black of night to work on my research. However, on some nights the moon was so bright it allowed you to move around outside. The beautifully haunting pictures remind me of shining my own flashlight on the faces of people I would meet at night. I have come to call the moon (whenever I see it here in Brooklyn) an African moon because I know it is lighting up the lives of my family and friends in Ghana when there is not electricity to do so. Even now when I travel back every summer to stay with friends in Accra or Kumasi, there is a scheduled time for "lights off". We know exactly when it is coming and expect and anticipate it, In spite of this, I always exclaim, "OH!!" And then we light the candles or turn on the battery charged lights and pull out the cards and board games.
Thank you for showing my Ghana at night.

Thanks, Mr. Kristof, for consistently writing about this mind-blowingly difficult and complex topic.

What can we do to reorient people in America to action? Given that we've produced 90% of carbon in the atmosphere that is now warming the planet, it is we who must make act with no delay to solve the problem. Of course, inherent in any effective solution is implementing diverse, integrated and concerted approaches that must be continually renewed regardless of administration changes. Approaches should include conserving a lot and generating a lot of what we must use from the sun and the wind.

But first, we as a nation must be convinced that we are near the beaker's boiling point. I fear your readers and commenters are not representive of mainstream thinking on this topic which has been as other commenters point out heavily influenced by the Bush legacy of denial and inaction (really worse than inaction, but that is another topic).

What will it take to change the way people think about energy consumption, and its impact on today and tomorrow's weather? And to convince individuals that they have a meaningful role in curbing consumption of energy and switching to alternate fuel sources where possible?

The classic Health Belief Model states that people must believe they are susceptible to a threat and that the consequences are serious. Yet in order to take action, they must also believe the barriers to action (like using less electricity) are easily overcome and that there are immediate rewards to taking a desired action (like an energy rebate, as Mr. Kristof suggests).

There are several missing links in establishing the global warming threat in the minds of many Americans. It seems like a partnership between industry and non-profits could launch an educational campaign to reinforce the (immediate) threat that all people are quite susceptible to (shrinking glaciers = hotter summers in 2010, and increasingly extreme storms that kill people). If people saw the images that Mr. Breashers sees at regular intervals, on TV, on buses, on billboards, more people would be willing to acknowledge that global warming is clearly happening now at a very rapid pace.

To be effective, campaigners conveying this serious and tangible threat must use them alongside a menu of actions that can make a difference. Action should include policy changes at the national level (global players are also important to avert future warming, but let's get real--Americans are responsible for nearly all of the climate change now occurring). Action should definitely also include changes at the personal level because that is how people come to realize they can use less energy, and it's really not that hard. Small actions pave the way for supporting bigger, meaningful reforms in the way we as a nation utilize energy.

I've said to many that DENIAL is not only a trait shared by people for millennia globally but common enough today. It takes many forms. A man writing on "Calling All Fanatics" in current online issue of Orion says it better than I: "Denial is a key obstacle to a better world; it is just as real as a massive concrete wall separating people from truths that should be obviously apparent. Denial is a feature of all addictiions. Our present culture is addicted to cheap and easy enjoyments, ultimately meaningless games of acquistion and consumption. We are averse to things that are difficult and challenging to our comfortable assumptions. Finding ways to help people break through their denial is a necessary first step towards their changing their miinds and ultimately their behavior." Mr. Kristoff, as a person respected for shrewd insights and clear expression of them in NYT, would you agree that the observation quoted is powerful?

I am totally convinced that there overall glacier mass is declining. However, it is worth acknowledging that this is not universally the case. For example, Karakoram glaciers are generally doing well, even expanding due to their very high area of catchment.  One problem has been the "all or nothing" approach, the worst case being the wild exagerations on both sides like "all himalaya glaciers will be gone in a generation" (in one UN report) versus "all global warming is made up (the entrenched nay sayers)."

For all the shouting about melting ice, the Gore-Al Warming community does a poor job of 1. connecting the dots in layman's language and 2. explaining a relief methodology that guarantees a reversal of the trend.
We all know the Ice Age came and went without man's catalytic interference. We all know man uses carbon fueled energy today. We know we have fewer forests than 100 years ago. Isn't this a more powerful degrading air quality force than too many SUVs? In the U.S. we switched to unleaded gasoline, catalytic converters, and ethanol blends decades ago. Our air certainly seems better today than in 1975. Why is Gore-Al warming increasing as we have gotten cleaner? Isn't China the world's leading polluter today? Of course, the U.S. doesn't have the economic power any longer to strong arm the Chinese.
Really, do scientists (and actually there are few true environmental scientists) really believe that people in the U.S. are against clean air and clean water? When a cleaner, more efficient automobile engine is built people will buy it. The MPG ratings on autos are not a measure of pollutant particles being launched into the atmosphere. It will be easier to win over the commitment of people to sacrifice convenience in return for a cleaner, safer world if they are given an explainble, logical plan to follow.
Just out of curiosity. The article mentions that NASA says we are experiencing the warmest year on the planet since records have been kept. What year currently holds that title. It isn't mentioned.

Those who continue to ignore and deny global warming and climate change likely love their gas guzzling SUV's, find recycling an inconvenience and never bother to turn off lights that aren't necessary. They can continue living their selfish, greedy, wasteful lives, not giving a rip about future generations, including their own offspring.

China and India will make these changes because it is in their interest to do so: Once the US starts down this path, the whole developed world will have committed to a low carbon future, and the Chinese in particular want to produce the technologies the developed countries want to buy. The Chinese appear to be investing in renewable energy technologies with this possibility in mind (see http://www.pewglobalwarming.org... ), but without the US making a real commitment, it's much less of a sure thing for them and the development of these technologies will proceed much less rapidly than it could.

We need a price on carbon to create business certainty and encourage the doing that will result in learning. The fundamental flaw in the "do R&D because that's all we can agree on" approach is that learning by doing requires that we DO. It's all about deployment and starting down the right path. We will need new technologies in the medium term but there are many currently available options that are either pay for themselves or are very cheap (see for example, http://www.mckinsey.com... ), so we need policies that will get us to implement them, and soon. And a carbon price is at the top of the list, at least for the utility sector.

Jon

South Africa is home to 93% of the world’s population of rhinos. Since the beginning of 2010, 124 rhinos have been killed in just South Africa. 5 of the 124 rhinos were Black Rhinos, which are on the endangered species list. As of right now, rhino poaching has passed last years total of 122 .This article got me thinking about what people are doing to stop this increase in rhino poaching.
Some national parks in South Africa have upgraded their equipment to keep up with poacher’s technology. The national parks now have night-vision equipment, modern radio equipment, and sometimes use tracking devices on the rhinos http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/south-africa/100714/south-african-rhinos-under-fire?page=0,0)) .Krueger National park is one of the hardest hit parks in Africa, they have lost 33 rhinos.
The National Wildlife Crime Reaction Unit (NWCRU) was developed to get a handle on this increase in rhino poaching (http://www.sanparks.org/about/news/2010/may/rhino_poaching.php). The NWCRU is made up of people from the SAPS (South African police service) Organised Crime Unit, SAN (South African National) Parks Environmental Crime Unit, the Provincial Conservation Anti-Poaching Unit and Prosecutors at a national and provincial level. The NWCRU was developed to help speed up the prosecuting process of suspected poachers. Right now there are about 25 suspected poachers that have been arrested (http://www.boston.com/news/science/articles/2010/05/29/poaching_of_rhinos_in_s_africa_on_rise/).
The most recent conviction was that of Xuan Hoang. On March 29, 2010 Hoang was arrested at Tambo International Airport for possession of 7 rhino horns. Hoang was convicted on June 30, 2010 . He was sentences to 10 years imprisonment (https://www.givengain.com/cgi-bin/giga.cgi?cmd=cause_dir_news_item&cause_id=2347&news_id=89308).
The head of Endangered Wildlife Trust’s Rhinos Security project Faan Coetzee, works with private land owners on protecting their rhinos. He suggests that land owners should have some one who will watch over the rhino’s full time (rhino monitors). These rhino monitors should not keep the same patrol patterns; this will make it hard to poachers to learn their patterns. Because the price for rhino horns is so enticing, rhino monitors should be watched carefully because poachers may try to bribe them. Also, Coetzee suggest that landowners and rhino monitors keep a camera on them at all times to be able to collect evidence if needed. Pictures may be needed to convict a poacher.
Another step both private land owners and reserves are taking to protect rhinos is dehorning them. They believe that by dehorning rhinos decreases their chances of being targeted by poachers. Unfortunately, Dehorning does not fully protect rhinos from poachers, because the horn cannot be entirely removed. Also poachers work at night, so sometimes poachers cannot tell if the rhino has been dehorned or not (http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/south-africa/100714/south-african-rhinos-under-fire?page=0,1).

-Jana Caine
